item.title: I have a simple question, should be easy for most people to answer
item.dc:creator: @runefreak10 runefreak10
item.description:
@runefreak10 wrote:

It’s all confusing.

This post would be the best way to explain it:

[317] Completely Server-Sided Clan Chat (uses music interface)

I already did. I added this and modified it so when you make a clan chat, it saves in your char file and you may leave and go to another clan chat while yours still exists for others to go into (while you’re online, of course. But I’ll be making it so people can join your chat while you’re offline.) Still working on it lots.

Like… Let’s say I log out and the string equals “Test”. I would log back in and it would equal “Test”, but then if I had something like if(exampleString == “Test”) { whatever the action I put, it won’t do it. So it says it’s “Test” but anything where I ask for it, it doesn’t do anything. I know it’s “Test” when I log on because it says it in my char file and I made a command to check the string and tell me what it’s set to.

Read full topic

item.title: I have a simple question, should be easy for most people to answer
item.dc:creator: @runefreak10 runefreak10
item.description:
@runefreak10 wrote:

Alright, hopefully in this topic I can get a reply, and not have it be a “0 replies” topic.

Since a character file in a 317 server all consist of nothing but integers that are being saved into it, that leads me to my question: How can I make the character file save a string that holds text into the character file?

The way it saves an integer:

public int blank = 0;

characterfile.write("character-blank = ", 0, 18); characterfile.write(Integer.toString(blank), 0, Integer.toString(blank).length()); characterfile.newLine();

} else if (token.equals("character-blank")) { blank = Integer.parseInt(token2);

I think this is the way a string would save:

public String blank = "-Blank-"

characterfile.write("character-blank = ", 0, 18); characterfile.write(blank, 0, blank.length()); characterfile.newLine();

} else if (token.equals("character-blank")) { blank = (token2);

But when I did that and I tried to do the thing that I added it for, it wasn’t working. Is that correct or not?

Read full topic
item.source: I have a simple question, should be easy for most people to answer
